Confidential | CyberComply  8 
 
Findings  Details  
 
#1. Insecure Backup Configuration  
SEVERITY:  HIGH  
 
STATUS: CLOSED  
 
LOCATION:  APK  file 
 
DESCRIPTION:  The application data can be backed up because the [android:allowBackup] flag is missing 
from the app's manifest file. This default setting allows Android to include the app's data in system backups, 
which can be restored when the app is reinstalled or installed on a new device. While convenient for users, 
this can pose a security risk if sensitive data is inadvertently included in the backups.  
 
IMPACT : Sensitive information, such as user credentials, personal data, or proprietary application data, can 
be included in backups and potentially accessed by unauthorized parties if the backup is compromised.  
 
PROOF  OF VULNERABILITY:  
 
 
 
 
android:allowBackup  attribute is  set to " false" in the AndroidManifest.xml  hence it is  not a finding  (Closed) . 
 
RECOMMENDATIONS : 
Explicitly set the [android:allowBackup] attribute to false in the application’s manifest file to prevent 
Android from including the app's data in system backups.  
<application >  android:allowBackup="false"  </application>

Confidential | CyberComply  9 
 
#2. Missing Root Detection in Android App  
SEVERITY:  HIGH  
 
STATUS: CLOSED  
 
LOCATION:  APK file  
 
DESCRIPTION:  The Android app lacks proper root detection mechanisms, which can lead to security 
vulnerabilities. Root detection is a critical security measure that prevents the app from running on rooted 
devices. Without root detection, the app becomes susceptible to various security risks, including 
unauthorized access to sensitive data, tampering with the app's functionality, and exploitation by malicious 
actors.  
 
IMPACT : Rooted devices bypass Android's security mechanisms, making it easier for malicious actors to 
manipulate the app and extract sensitive information.  Compromise of user data: Without root detection, 
attackers can gain unrestricted access to the app's data stored on the device, compromising the privacy and 
security of user information.  Loss of trust and credibility: Users may lose trust in the app and its developers 
if it fails to implement basic security measures like root detection, leading to reputational damage and loss of 
credibility.  
 
PROOF  OF VULNERABILITY:

Confidential | CyberComply  10 
 
 
Application is not installing in the rooted device , Rooted detection is enabled , hence it is  not a finding  (Closed) . 
 
RECOMMENDATIONS : 
Integrate robust root detection techniques into the app to identify rooted devices and prevent the app 
from running on such devices.  
Use reputable root detection libraries: Utilize established root detection libraries and frameworks that 
provide reliable detection capabilities and stay updated with the latest security threats.

Confidential | CyberComply  11 
 
#3. Installation on Vulnerable, Unpatched Android Versions  
SEVERITY:  MEDIUM  
 
STATUS: CLOSED  
 
LOCATION:  APK  file 
 
DESCRIPTION:  The application can be installed on a vulnerable, unpatched version of Android (Android 
7.0, minSdk=24). This poses a security risk as older versions of Android often contain known vulnerabilities 
that have been patched in later versions. By allowing insta llation on these outdated platforms, the application 
may be exposed to potential security threats that could compromise user data and application integrity.  
 
IMPACT:   
• Exploitation of Known Vulnerabilities: Older versions of Android, such as Android 7.0, have well -
documented security flaws. Attackers can exploit these vulnerabilities to gain unauthorized access to 
sensitive data, escalate privileges, or execute arbitrary  code.  
• Increased Attack Surface: By supporting outdated Android versions, the application broadens its 
attack surface, making it more susceptible to various types of cyber -attacks.  
• Data Breach Risks: The presence of unpatched security flaws increases the likelihood of data breaches, 
which can lead to significant financial and reputational damage.  
 
PROOF  OF VULNERABILITY:  
 
 
 
App is using the updated  version hence it is  not a finding ( Closed) .  
 
RECOMMENDATIONS : 
Increase minSdk Version: Update the minSdkVersion  in the app’s build configuration to a more recent 
version of Android that is known to have fewer vulnerabilities. For example, setting minSdkVersion to 
26 (Android 8.0) or higher.  
android {  
    defaultConfig {  
        minSdkVersion 26  
    } 
}

Confidential | CyberComply  12 
 
#4. Missing V1, V2, V4 Signature in Android APK  
SEVERITY:  LOW  
STATUS:  CLOSED  
 
LOCATION:   APK  file 
 
DESCRIPTION : The Missing V4 Signature Vulnerability pertains to the absence of the V4 signature scheme in 
Android application packages (APKs). This signature scheme, introduced to bolster security measures, ensures the 
integrity and authenticity of Android applications. The absence of the V4 signature indicates a deviation from 
recommended security practices, potentially exposing the application to un authorized modifications or tampering.  
 
IMPACT : The vulnerability leaves the application susceptible to various security risks, including unauthorized 
modifications, tampering, or the insertion of malicious components. Without the V4 signature, attackers could exploit 
vulnerabilities in the application, leading to data breaches, unauthorized access, or other security compromises.  
 
PROOF  OF VULNERABILITY:  
 
APK Signature Scheme V3, V4 is  present,  Hence it is  not a finding  (Closed) .  
 
RECOMMENDATIONS : 
To address this vulnerability, developers must update their signing process to include the generation of the V4 
signature scheme using tools like Android Studio or the Android SDK. By adopting the latest signing practices, 
developers can enhance the securi ty and integrity of their applications, mitigating the risk of exploitation and 
unauthorized modifications.

Confidential | CyberComply  13 
 
Conclusion  
Following the conclusion of the engagement, findings will be made available via CyberComply . The 
deliverables will be both strategic and tactical in nature, presented in a drill -down format that will be 
highly accessible to both management and operational staff. Each finding will have a risk scoring 
associated with it as well as contain detailed technical information pertaining to the nature of the 
finding. Each finding will also be presented with clear guidance on how to remediate the issue.

9		OVERVIEW OF OPERATIONS Company	Background	Sharpsell	is	a	sales	playbook	automation	platform,	headquartered	in	Mumbai	with	a	development	center	in	Bangalore,	India.	They	partner	with	customers	across	retail,	financial	services,	high	tech,	pharmaceuticals,	and	other	industries	to	help	them	drive	sales	productivity.	Description	of	Services	Provided	Sharpsell.ai	is	Sales	Playbook	Automation	Platform	helps	large	sales	teams	to	scale	deal-winning	behaviour	with	dynamic	product	illustrations,	real-time	learning,	and	personalized	content.	Sharpsell	comes	with	playbooks	for	sales	people	that	adapt	and	serve	them	every	step	of	the	sales	process	by	providing	learning,	content,	tools,	frameworks	and	answers	that	are	required	to	build	trust	and	close	deals.		Sharpsell	is	used	by	leading	companies	by	7,00,000+	frontline	sales	users	across	industries.

Processes,	Policies	and	Procedures	Formal	IT	policies	and	procedures	exist	that	describe	physical	security,	logical	access,	computer	operations,	change	control,	and	data	communication	standards.	All	teams	are	expected	to	adhere	to	the	Sharpsell	policies	and	procedures	that	define	how	services	should	be	delivered.	These	are	located	on	the	Company’s	intranet	and	can	be	accessed	by	any	Sharpsell	team	member.

13			Physical	Security	Physical	protection	shall	be	achieved	by	creating	several	physical	barriers	around	Sharpsell’s	premises	and	information	processing	facilities.	Each	barrier	shall	establish	a	security	perimeter,	creating	a	defense	in	depth	strategy	and	eliminating	a	single	point	of	failure.	Logical	Access	Logical	Access	controls	shall	be	deployed	with	the	principle	of	‘deny	all	unless	explicitly	permitted’	to	protect	information	from	unauthorized	access.	Customers,	third-party	vendors	and	service	providers	shall	be	provided	access	 to	 Sharpsell’s	 information	 assets	 only	 upon	 presenting	 business	 needs	 and	 signing	 the	 contractual	agreement.	Access	to	this	network	is	protected	by	user	id	and	password-based	access.	For	the	internal	office	networks,	there	is	access	control	via	user	id	and	password	to	various	resources.	During	the	hiring	and	termination	process,	HR	follows	the	access	activation	and	deactivation	procedure.		Computer	Operations	-	Backups	This	procedure	applies	to	all	individuals	who	access,	use	and	control	Sharpsell’s	owned	resources.	This	includes	but	is	limited	to	Sharpsell’s	employees,	contractors,	consultants,	and	other	workers.	The	Head	of	Departments	/	Business	Units	shall	clearly	identify	the	data	to	be	backup,	the	minimum	backup	frequency	and	archival	rules	for	the	respective	asset.	The	IT	Department	is	responsible	for	the	implementation	of	a	Backup	plan	for	the	servers.	There	is	a	limited	number	of	people	within	the	organization	who	have	the	ability	to	download	or	restore	a	particular	backup	Computer		Operations	–	Availability	The	SAAS	services	by	AWS	have	a	certain	reliability	which	is	leveraged	for	providing	the	services	to	our	customers.	Availability	may	still	be	hampered	by	spikes	in	usage	or	performance	issues.	For	that	purpose,	a	high	availability	cluster	spanning	multiple	nodes	and	managed	by	Kubernetes	is	created	so	that	the	system	is	available	despite	such	situations.	Change	Management	This	policy	establishes	a	standard	procedure	for	managing	change	requests	in	an	agile	and	efficient	manner,	to	 drastically	 minimize	 the	 risk	 and	 impact	 a	 change	 which	 can	 have	 on	 the	 business	 operations	 of	 the	company.	The	change	management	process	begins	with	the	creation	of	a	Change	Request	within	the	company’s	selected	technology	platform.	It	ends	with	the	satisfactory	implementation	of	the	change	and	communication	of	the	result	of	that	change	to	all	interested	parties.	Further	Reporting	shall	be	a	part	of	the	entire	process,	at	every	step.	Change	Management	is	a	continuous	improvement	within	the	IT	systems	of	the	company	and	it	generally	including	the	following	steps	:	1. Prioritize	and	respond	to	the	change	proposals.

14		2. Conduct	a	cost-benefit	analysis	of	the	proposed	changes.		3. Assessment	of	risk	associated	with	the	changes.	4. Change	implementation	and	monitoring.	Firewalls	Firewalls	are	in	place	to	ensure	that	there	is	no	unauthorized	access	of	Organization’s	resources.	The	firewalls	have	monitoring	logs,	and	they	are	reviewed	on	a	periodic	basis.	In	addition,	remote	access	is	made	available	via	VPN	for	restricted	set	of	users	for	a	specified	time.	This	set	of	user	access	is	also	reviewed	on	a	periodic	basis.	Boundaries	of	the	System	The	scope	of	this	report	includes	the	Sharpsell	application.	It	also	includes	the	people,	processes,	and	IT	systems	that	are	required	to	achieve	our	service	commitments	toward	the	customers	of	this	application.		Sharpsell	may	depend	on	a	number	of	vendors	to	achieve	its	objectives.	The	scope	of	this	report	does	not	include	the	processes	and	controls	performed	by	the	vendors.		The	management	understands	that	risks	exist	when	engaging	with	vendors	and	has	formulated	a	process	for	managing	such	risks,	as	detailed	in	the	Risk	Assessment	section	of	this	document.	This	report	does	not	include	the	data	center	hosting	services	provided	by	AWS.

15		Relevant Aspects of the Control Environment, Risk Assessment Process, Information and Communication and Monitoring Control	Environment	Integrity	and	Ethical	Values	Integrity	and	ethical	values,	while	they	are	not	something	that	can	be	enforced	via	policy	documents,	can	be	promoted	by	creating	an	environment	and	culture	that	makes	it	easier	to	have	integrity	and	be	ethical	than	not.	Employees	undergo	training	related	to	expected	standards	of	behavior	and	ethics,	they	are	also	asked	to	go	through	policy	documents	related	to	ethics	and	integrity	during	their	orientation.	Specific	control	activities	that	the	service	organization	has	implemented	in	this	area	are	described	below:	● Formally,	 documented	 organizational	 policy	 statements	 and	 codes	 of	 conduct	 communicate	 entity	values	and	behavioral	standards	to	personnel.	● Policies	and	procedures	require	employees	to	sign	an	acknowledgement	form	indicating	they	have	been	given	access	to	the	employee	manual	and	understand	their	responsibility	for	adhering	to	the	policies	and	procedures	contained	within	the	manual.	● A	confidentiality	statement	agreeing	not	to	disclose	proprietary	or	confidential	information,	including	client	information,	to	unauthorized	parties	is	a	component	of	the	employee	handbook.	● Background	checks	are	performed	for	employees	as	a	component	of	the	hiring	process.	Commitment	to	Competence	An	annual	performance	appraisal	is	held	for	all	employees,	which	is	based	on	a	points	system.	The	 employees	 are	 incentivized	 to	 improve	 their	 skills	 and	 be	 more	 productive.	 Pay	 revisions	 and	compensation	improvements	and	promotions	are	linked	to	the	performance	appraisal.	Specific	control	activities	that	the	service	organization	has	implemented	in	this	area	are	described	below:	● Management	has	considered	the	competence	levels	for	specific	jobs	and	translated	required	skills	and	knowledge	levels	into	written	position	requirements.	● Training	is	provided	to	maintain	the	skill	level	of	personnel	in	certain	positions.	Management’s	Philosophy	and	Operating	Style	Management	philosophy	for	the	organization	is	based	on	the	premise	that	focusing	on	the	customer’s	long	term	needs	rather	than	providing	short	term	solutions	is	a	more	beneficial	policy	in	the	long	run.	In	 addition,	 management	 believes	 that	 the	 changing	 regulatory	 environment	 as	 well	 as	 improvements	 in	technology	provide	business	opportunities,	so	it	is	important	to	stay	up	to	date	on	these,	they	must	be	looked	at	as	opportunities	rather	than	problems.	Specific	control	activities	that	the	service	organization	has	implemented	in	this	area	are	described	below:	● Management	is	periodically	briefed	on	regulatory	and	industry	changes	affecting	the	services	provided.

16		● Executive	management	meetings	are	held	to	discuss	major	initiatives	and	issues	that	affect	the	business.		Organizational	Structure	and	Assignment	of	Authority	and	Responsibility		Sharpsell's	organizational	structure	provides	the	framework	within	which	its	activities	for	achieving	entity-wide	objectives	are	planned,	executed,	controlled,	and	monitored.	Management	believes	that	establishing	a	relevant	 organizational	 structure	 includes	 considering	 key	 areas	 of	 authority	 and	 responsibility.	 An	organizational	structure	has	been	developed	to	suit	its	needs.	This	organizational	structure	is	based,	in	part,	on	its	size	and	the	nature	of	its	activities.		The	 management	 is	 committed	 to	 maintaining	 and	 improving	 its	 framework	 for	 how	 authority	 and	responsibility	 for	 operating	 activities	 are	 assigned	 and	 how	 reporting	 relationships	 and	 authorization	hierarchies	are	established.	This	also	includes	policies	relating	to	appropriate	business	practices,	knowledge,	and	experience	of	key	personnel,	and	resources	provided	for	carrying	out	duties.		In	addition,	it	includes	policies	and	communications	directed	at	ensuring	personnel	understand	the	entity's	objectives,	know	how	their	individual	actions	interrelate	and	contribute	to	those	objectives,	and	recognize	how	and	for	what	they	will	be	held	accountable.	Organizational	charts	are	in	place	to	communicate	key	areas	of	authority	and	responsibility.	These	charts	are	accessible	to	all	employees	of	the	company	and	are	updated	as	required.		The	goal	of	the	organization	is	to	have	lean	and	agile	teams.	However,	every	team	member	is	part	of	a	formal	hierarchy	that	rolls	up	to	the	CEO.	While	employees	and	multiple	teams	may	collaborate	informally	to	get	things	done	faster,	in	case	of	conflicts	or	deciding	how	something	new	would	be	handled,	the	formal	hierarchy	is	used	as	the	basis	for	coming	to	conclusions.	It	is	also	ensured	that	collaborative	work	does	not	mean	sharing	of	confidential	data	or	credentials	that	must	not	be	shared	with	unauthorized	persons.	Specific	control	activities	that	the	service	organization	has	implemented	in	this	area	are	described	below:	● Organizational	charts	are	in	place	to	communicate	key	areas	of	authority	and	responsibility.	● Organizational	charts	are	communicated	to	employees	and	updated	as	needed.	Human	Resources	Policies	and	Practices	The	human	resource	department	under	the	direction	of	the	board	and	the	leadership	directs	the	policies	and	procedures	such	that	there	is:	● Delivery	excellence	● an	environment	where	merit	and	performance	are	valued.	● people	feel	part	of	something	bigger	than	them.	● a	high-performance	work	ethic	There	are	policies	that	dictate	induction	of	new	joiners,	exit	and	termination	policies	as	well	as	promotions	that	lead	to	achieving	the	goals	listed	above.

17		Risk	Assessment		Sharpsell’s	assessment	process	identifies	and	manages	risks	that	could	potentially	affect	Sharpsell’s	ability	to	provide	reliable	services	to	its	customers.	This	ongoing	process	requires	that	management	identify	significant	risks	inherent	in	products	or	services	as	they	oversee	their	areas	of	responsibility.	The	Sharpsell	identifies	the	underlying	sources	of	risk,	measures	the	impact	on	the	organization,	and	implements	appropriate	measures	to	monitor	and	manage	the	risks.	This	process	has	identified	risks	resulting	from	the	nature	of	the	services	provided	by	Sharpsell’	s	management	has	implemented	various	measures	designed	to	manage	these	risks.	Risks	identified	in	this	process	include	the	following:	● Operational	risk	-	changes	in	the	environment	and	critical	staff	● Strategic	risk	-	new	technologies,	changing	business	models,	and	shifts	within	the	industry.	● Compliance	-	legal	and	regulatory	changes	Sharpsell	has	established	an	internal	team	responsible	for	identifying	risks	to	the	entity	and	monitoring	the	operation	of	the	firm’s	internal	controls.	Sharpsell	attempts	to	actively	identify	and	mitigate	significant	risks	through	 the	 implementation	 of	 various	 initiatives	 and	 continuous	 communication	 with	 other	 leadership	committees	and	senior	management.	Information	and	Communications	Systems	It	 is	 important	 for	 the	customer	 and	 internal	 stakeholders	 to	 be	 aware	 of	 the	 changes	 to	 be	 made	 to	 the	production	systems	as	well	as	the	reasons	for	that.	The	same	applies	to	communications	after	the	changes	have	been	made	or	rolled	back.	Similarly,	a	new	initiative	taken	internally	to	add	product	features	or	to	improve	the	systems	in	any	other	way	needs	to	be	communicated	to	the	team	and	responsibilities	need	to	be	assigned.	That	requires	a	robust	and	efficient	mode	of	communication	that	is	also	secure.	Various	degrees	and	means	of	communication	are	required	for	interaction	with	prospects,	live	customers	and	employees.	In	addition,	it	is	required	to	keep	track	of	the	communications	as	well	as	what	actions	have	been	taken	to	achieve	the	goals.	Monitoring	Controls	Being	a	cloud-based	system,	the	monitoring	is	via	logs,	which	may	be	application	logs	as	well	as	access	logs.		A	dedicated	support	team	monitors	all	the	production	systems	24	x	7	and	keeps	an	eye	out	for	anomalies.	The	support	team	also	receives	issues	raised	by	the	customer	and	attempts	to	correlate	the	customer’s	findings	with	the	corresponding	logs,	thereby	pre-empting	a	customer	report	by	taking	corrective	action	even	before	it	is	reported	by	them.	Log	monitoring	is	also	used	to	pass	on	valuable	information	to	the	development	teams	to	solve	issues	that	cannot	be	simulated	in	a	development	environment.	On-Going	Monitoring

18		Sharpsell’s	management	conducts	quality	assurance	monitoring	on	a	regular	basis	and	additional	training	is	provided	based	upon	results	of	monitoring	procedures.	Monitoring	activities	are	used	to	initiate	corrective	action	through	department	meetings,	internal	conference	calls,	and	informal	notifications.	Management’s	 close	 involvement	in	 Sharpsell’s	 operations	 helps	 to	 identify	 significant	 variances	 from	expectations	regarding	internal	controls.	Upper	management	evaluates	the	facts	and	circumstances	related	to	any	suspected	control	breakdown.	A	decision	for	addressing	any	control’s	weakness	is	made	based	on	whether	the	 incident	 was	 isolated	 or	 requires	 a	 change	 in	 the	 company’s	 procedures	 or	 personnel.	 The	 goal	 of	 this	process	is	to	ensure	legal	compliance	and	to	maximize	the	performance	of	Sharpsell’s	personnel.	Reporting	Deficiencies	An	 internal	 tracking	 tool	 is	 utilized	 to	 document	 and	 track	 the	 results	 of	 on-going	 monitoring	 procedures.	Escalation	procedures	are	maintained	for	responding	and	notifying	management	of	any	identified	risks.	Risks	receiving	a	high	rating	are	responded	to	immediately.	Corrective	actions,	if	necessary,	are	documented	and	tracked	within	the	internal	tracking	tool.	Annual	risk	meetings	are	held	for	management	to	review	reported	deficiencies	and	corrective	actions.	Changes	to	the	System	Since	the	Last	Review	Since	 the	 organisation's	 last	 review,	 no	 significant	 changes	 have	 occurred	 to	 the	 services	 provided	 to	 user	entities.	Incidents	Since	the	Last	Review	Since	the	organisation's	last	review,	no	significant	incidents	have	occurred	with	the	services	provided	to	user	entities.	Applicable	Trust	Service	Criteria	and	Related	Controls	The	 security,	 availability	 and	 confidentiality	 trust	 services	 categories	 and	 Sharpsell’s	 related	 controls	 are	included	 in	 section	 4	 of	 this	 report,	 “Independent	 Service	Auditor's	 Description	 of	 Tests	 of	 Controls	 and	Results”.	 Sharpsell	 has	 determined	 that	 Processing	 Integrity	 and	 Privacy	 trust	 services	 Categories	 are	 not	relevant	to	the	system.	Subservice	Organizations	This	report	does	not	include	the	data	center	hosting	services	provided	by	AWS	at	multiple	facilities.	Subservice	Description	of	Services	The	SAAS	services	provided	by	AWS	are	monitored	by	management;	however,	they	have	not	been	included	in	the	scope	of	this	review.	Complementary	Subservice	Organization	Controls	Sharpsell’s	services	are	designed	with	the	assumption	that	certain	controls	will	be	implemented	by	subservice	organizations.	Such	controls	are	called	complementary	subservice	organization	controls.	It	is	not	feasible	for	all	 of	 the	 trust	 services	 criteria	 related	 to	 the	 Sharpsell	 services	 to	 be	 solely	 achieved	 by	 Sharpsell	 control	procedures.	Accordingly,	subservice	organizations,	in	conjunction	with	the	services,	should	establish	their	own	internal	controls	or	procedures	to	complement	those	of	Sharpsell.

19		The	following	subservice	organization	controls	should	be	implemented	by	AWS	to	provide	additional	assurance	that	the	trust	services	criteria	described	within	this	report	are	met.		Subservice	Organization	–	AWS	Category	Criteria	Applicable	Controls	Common	Criteria/Security	CC6.4	Physical	access	to	data	centers	is	approved	by	an	authorized	individual.	Physical	access	is	revoked	within	24	hours	of	the	employee	or	vendor	record	being	deactivated.	Physical	access	to	data	centers	is	reviewed	on	a	quarterly	basis	by	appropriate	personnel.	Physical	access	points	to	server	locations	are	recorded	by	closed	circuit	television	camera	(CCTV).	Images	are	retained	for	60	days,	unless	limited	by	legal	or	contractual	obligations.	Physical	access	points	to	server	locations	are	managed	by	electronic	access	control	devices.	Availability	A1.2	Electronic	intrusion	detection	systems	are	installed	within	data	server	locations	to	monitor,	detect,	and	automatically	alert	appropriate	personnel	of	security	incidents.		Sharpsell	 management,	 along	 with	 the	 subservice	 organization,	 define	 the	 scope	 and	 responsibility	 of	 the	controls	necessary	to	meet	all	the	relevant	trust	services	criteria	through	written	contracts,	such	as	service	level	agreements.	In	addition,	Sharpsell	performs	monitoring	of	the	subservice	organization	controls,	including	the	following	procedures.	● Reviewing	attestation	reports	over	services	provided	by	vendors	and	subservice	organizations.		Complementary	Customer	Control	(CUEC)		Sharpsell’s	controls	related	to	Sharpsell	cover	a	subset	of	overall	internal	control	for	each	user	of	the	software	application.	The	control	objectives	related	to	Sharpsell	cannot	be	achieved	solely	by	the	controls	put	in	place	by	Sharpsell;	each	customer's	internal	controls	need	to	be	considered	along	with	Sharpsell’s	controls.	Each	customer	must	evaluate	its	own	internal	control	to	determine	whether	the	identified	complementary	customer	controls	have	been	implemented	and	are	operating	effectively.

2		  INDEPENDENT SERVICE AUDITOR’S REPORT To	Sharpsell	Technology	Solutions	Pvt.	Ltd.	Independent	 Service	 Auditors’	 Report	 on	 Description	 of	 Sharpsell	 Technology	 Solutions	 Pvt. Scope	We	have	examined	Sharpsell	Technology	Solutions	Pvt.	Ltd.’s	(the	“Service	Organization”	or	“Sharpsell”)	accompanying	System	Description	Provided	by	Service	Organization	of	its	system	for	Sharpsell	Platform	software	as	a	service	for	the	period	from	March	01,	2023	to	August	31,	2023	(Description)	in	accordance	with	the	criteria	for	a	description	of	a	service	organization’s	system	set	forth	in	the	Description	Criteria	DC	section	200	2018	Description	Criteria	for	a	Description	of	a	Service	Organization’s	System	in	a	SOC	2	Report	(Description	Criteria)	and	the	suitability	of	the	design	and	operating	effectiveness	of	controls	included	in	the	Description	for	the	period	from	March	01,	2023	to	August	31,	2023	to	provide	reasonable	assurance	that	the	service	commitments	and	system	requirements	were	achieved	based	on	the	trust	services	criteria	for	Security,	Availability	and	Confidentiality	(applicable	trust	services	criteria)	set	forth	in	TSP	section	100,	2017	Trust	Services	Criteria	for	Security,	Availability,	Processing	Integrity,	Confidentiality,	and	Privacy.		Sharpsell	 uses	 Amazon	 Web	 Services	 (AWS)	 (“Subservice	 Organization”)	 as	 cloud	 service	 providers.	 The	 Description	indicates	that	complementary	subservice	organization	controls	that	are	suitably	designed	and	operating	effectively	are	necessary,	along	with	controls	at	Sharpsell,	to	achieve	Sharpsell’s	service	commitments	and	system	requirements	based	on	 the	 applicable	 trust	 services	 criteria.	 The	 description	 presents	Sharpsell’	 system;	 its	 controls;	 and	 the	 types	 of	complementary	subservice	organization	controls	that	the	service	organization	assumes	have	been	implemented,	suitably	designed,	and	operating	effectively	at	subservice	organization.	Our	examination	did	not	extend	to	the	services	provided	by	subservice	organization	and	we	have	not	evaluated	whether	the	controls	management	assumes	have	been	implemented	at	subservice	organization	have	been	implemented	or	whether	such	controls	were	suitably	designed	and	operating	effectively	for	the	period	from	March	01,	2023	to	August	31,	2023.		The	description	indicates	that	complementary	user	entity	controls	that	are	suitably	designed	and	operating	effectively	are	necessary,	along	with	controls	at	Sharpsell,	to	achieve	the	service	commitments	and	system	requirements	based	on	the	applicable	trust	services	criteria.	The	description	presents	Sharpsell’s	controls,	the	applicable	trust	services	criteria,	and	the	complementary	user	entity	controls	assumed	in	the	design	of	Sharpsell’s	controls.	Our	examination	did	not	include	such	complementary	user	entity	controls	and	we	have	not	evaluated	the	suitability	of	the	design	or	operating	effectiveness	of	such	controls. An	 examination	 of	 a	 description	 of	 a	 service	 organization’s	 system	 and	 the	 suitability	 of	 the	 design	 and	 operating	effectiveness	of	the	controls	involves	the	following:	● Obtaining	an	understanding	of	the	system	and	the	service	organization’s	service	commitments	and	system	requirements	● Assessing	the	risks	that	the	description	is	not	presented	in	accordance	with	the	description	criteria	and	that	controls	were	not	suitably	designed	or	did	not	operate	effectively.	● Performing	procedures	to	obtain	evidence	about	whether	the	description	is	presented	in	accordance	with	the	description	criteria.	● Performing	procedures	to	obtain	evidence	about	whether	controls	stated	in	the	description	were	suitably	designed	to	 provide	 reasonable	 assurance	 that	 the	 service	 organization	 achieved	 its	 service	 commitments	 and	 system	requirements	based	on	the	applicable	trust	services	criteria.	● Testing	the	operating	effectiveness	of	controls	stated	in	the	description	to	provide	reasonable	assurance	that	the	service	organization	achieved	its	service	commitments	and	system	requirements	based	on	the	applicable	trust	services	criteria.	● Evaluating	the	overall	presentation	of	the	description.	Our	examination	also	included	performing	such	other	procedures	as	we	considered	necessary	in	the	circumstances.	Inherent	Limitations	The	description	is	prepared	to	meet	the	common	needs	of	a	broad	range	of	report	users	and	may	not,	therefore,	include	every	aspect	of	the	system	that	individual	users	may	consider	important	to	meet	their	informational	needs.	There	are	inherent	limitations	in	the	effectiveness	of	any	system	of	internal	control,	including	the	possibility	of	human	error	and	the	circumvention	of	controls.	Because	 of	 their	 nature,	 controls	 may	 not	 always	 operate	 effectively	 to	 provide	 reasonable	 assurance	 that	 the	 service	organization’s	service	commitments	and	system	requirements	are	achieved	based	on	the	applicable	trust	services	criteria.	Also,	the	projection	to	the	future	of	any	conclusion	about	the	suitability	of	the	design	or	operating	effectiveness	of	controls	may	become	inadequate	because	of	changes	in	conditions	or	the	degree	of	compliance	with	the	policies	or	procedures	may	deteriorate. Processes,	Policies	and	Procedures	Formal	IT	policies	and	procedures	exist	that	describe	physical	security,	logical	access,	computer	operations,	change	control,	and	data	communication	standards.	All	teams	are	expected	to	adhere	to	the	Sharpsell	policies	and	procedures	that	define	how	services	should	be	delivered.	These	are	located	on	the	Company’s	intranet	and	can	be	accessed	by	any	Sharpsell	team	member.

13			Physical	Security	Physical	protection	shall	be	achieved	by	creating	several	physical	barriers	around	Sharpsell’s	premises	and	information	processing	facilities.	Each	barrier	shall	establish	a	security	perimeter,	creating	a	defense	in	depth	strategy	and	eliminating	a	single	point	of	failure.	Logical	Access	Logical	Access	controls	shall	be	deployed	with	the	principle	of	‘deny	all	unless	explicitly	permitted’	to	protect	information	from	unauthorized	access.	Customers,	third-party	vendors	and	service	providers	shall	be	provided	access	 to	 Sharpsell’s	 information	 assets	 only	 upon	 presenting	 business	 needs	 and	 signing	 the	 contractual	agreement.	Access	to	this	network	is	protected	by	user	id	and	password-based	access.	For	the	internal	office	networks,	there	is	access	control	via	user	id	and	password	to	various	resources.	During	the	hiring	and	termination	process,	HR	follows	the	access	activation	and	deactivation	procedure.		Computer	Operations	-	Backups	This	procedure	applies	to	all	individuals	who	access,	use	and	control	Sharpsell’s	owned	resources.	This	includes	but	is	limited	to	Sharpsell’s	employees,	contractors,	consultants,	and	other	workers.	The	Head	of	Departments	/	Business	Units	shall	clearly	identify	the	data	to	be	backup,	the	minimum	backup	frequency	and	archival	rules	for	the	respective	asset.	The	IT	Department	is	responsible	for	the	implementation	of	a	Backup	plan	for	the	servers.	There	is	a	limited	number	of	people	within	the	organization	who	have	the	ability	to	download	or	restore	a	particular	backup	Computer		Operations	–	Availability	The	SAAS	services	by	AWS	have	a	certain	reliability	which	is	leveraged	for	providing	the	services	to	our	customers.	Availability	may	still	be	hampered	by	spikes	in	usage	or	performance	issues.	For	that	purpose,	a	high	availability	cluster	spanning	multiple	nodes	and	managed	by	Kubernetes	is	created	so	that	the	system	is	available	despite	such	situations.	Change	Management	This	policy	establishes	a	standard	procedure	for	managing	change	requests	in	an	agile	and	efficient	manner,	to	 drastically	 minimize	 the	 risk	 and	 impact	 a	 change	 which	 can	 have	 on	 the	 business	 operations	 of	 the	company.	The	change	management	process	begins	with	the	creation	of	a	Change	Request	within	the	company’s	selected	technology	platform.	It	ends	with	the	satisfactory	implementation	of	the	change	and	communication	of	the	result	of	that	change	to	all	interested	parties.	Further	Reporting	shall	be	a	part	of	the	entire	process,	at	every	step.	Change	Management	is	a	continuous	improvement	within	the	IT	systems	of	the	company	and	it	generally	including	the	following	steps	:	1. Prioritize	and	respond	to	the	change	proposals.

14		2. Conduct	a	cost-benefit	analysis	of	the	proposed	changes.		3. Assessment	of	risk	associated	with	the	changes.	4. Change	implementation	and	monitoring.	Firewalls	Firewalls	are	in	place	to	ensure	that	there	is	no	unauthorized	access	of	Organization’s	resources.	The	firewalls	have	monitoring	logs,	and	they	are	reviewed	on	a	periodic	basis.	In	addition,	remote	access	is	made	available	via	VPN	for	restricted	set	of	users	for	a	specified	time.	This	set	of	user	access	is	also	reviewed	on	a	periodic	basis.	Boundaries	of	the	System	The	scope	of	this	report	includes	the	Sharpsell	application.	It	also	includes	the	people,	processes,	and	IT	systems	that	are	required	to	achieve	our	service	commitments	toward	the	customers	of	this	application.		Sharpsell	may	depend	on	a	number	of	vendors	to	achieve	its	objectives.	The	scope	of	this	report	does	not	include	the	processes	and	controls	performed	by	the	vendors.		The	management	understands	that	risks	exist	when	engaging	with	vendors	and	has	formulated	a	process	for	managing	such	risks,	as	detailed	in	the	Risk	Assessment	section	of	this	document.	This	report	does	not	include	the	data	center	hosting	services	provided	by	AWS.

15		Relevant Aspects of the Control Environment, Risk Assessment Process, Information and Communication and Monitoring Control	Environment	Integrity	and	Ethical	Values	Integrity	and	ethical	values,	while	they	are	not	something	that	can	be	enforced	via	policy	documents,	can	be	promoted	by	creating	an	environment	and	culture	that	makes	it	easier	to	have	integrity	and	be	ethical	than	not.	Employees	undergo	training	related	to	expected	standards	of	behavior	and	ethics,	they	are	also	asked	to	go	through	policy	documents	related	to	ethics	and	integrity	during	their	orientation.	Specific	control	activities	that	the	service	organization	has	implemented	in	this	area	are	described	below:	● Formally,	 documented	 organizational	 policy	 statements	 and	 codes	 of	 conduct	 communicate	 entity	values	and	behavioral	standards	to	personnel.	● Policies	and	procedures	require	employees	to	sign	an	acknowledgement	form	indicating	they	have	been	given	access	to	the	employee	manual	and	understand	their	responsibility	for	adhering	to	the	policies	and	procedures	contained	within	the	manual.	● A	confidentiality	statement	agreeing	not	to	disclose	proprietary	or	confidential	information,	including	client	information,	to	unauthorized	parties	is	a	component	of	the	employee	handbook.	● Background	checks	are	performed	for	employees	as	a	component	of	the	hiring	process.	Commitment	to	Competence	An	annual	performance	appraisal	is	held	for	all	employees,	which	is	based	on	a	points	system.	The	 employees	 are	 incentivized	 to	 improve	 their	 skills	 and	 be	 more	 productive.	 Pay	 revisions	 and	compensation	improvements	and	promotions	are	linked	to	the	performance	appraisal.	Specific	control	activities	that	the	service	organization	has	implemented	in	this	area	are	described	below:	● Management	has	considered	the	competence	levels	for	specific	jobs	and	translated	required	skills	and	knowledge	levels	into	written	position	requirements.	● Training	is	provided	to	maintain	the	skill	level	of	personnel	in	certain	positions.	Management’s	Philosophy	and	Operating	Style	Management	philosophy	for	the	organization	is	based	on	the	premise	that	focusing	on	the	customer’s	long	term	needs	rather	than	providing	short	term	solutions	is	a	more	beneficial	policy	in	the	long	run.	In	 addition,	 management	 believes	 that	 the	 changing	 regulatory	 environment	 as	 well	 as	 improvements	 in	technology	provide	business	opportunities,	so	it	is	important	to	stay	up	to	date	on	these,	they	must	be	looked	at	as	opportunities	rather	than	problems.	Specific	control	activities	that	the	service	organization	has	implemented	in	this	area	are	described	below:	● Management	is	periodically	briefed	on	regulatory	and	industry	changes	affecting	the	services	provided.

16		● Executive	management	meetings	are	held	to	discuss	major	initiatives	and	issues	that	affect	the	business.		Organizational	Structure	and	Assignment	of	Authority	and	Responsibility		Sharpsell's	organizational	structure	provides	the	framework	within	which	its	activities	for	achieving	entity-wide	objectives	are	planned,	executed,	controlled,	and	monitored.	Management	believes	that	establishing	a	relevant	 organizational	 structure	 includes	 considering	 key	 areas	 of	 authority	 and	 responsibility.	 An	organizational	structure	has	been	developed	to	suit	its	needs.	This	organizational	structure	is	based,	in	part,	on	its	size	and	the	nature	of	its	activities.		The	 management	 is	 committed	 to	 maintaining	 and	 improving	 its	 framework	 for	 how	 authority	 and	responsibility	 for	 operating	 activities	 are	 assigned	 and	 how	 reporting	 relationships	 and	 authorization	hierarchies	are	established.	This	also	includes	policies	relating	to	appropriate	business	practices,	knowledge,	and	experience	of	key	personnel,	and	resources	provided	for	carrying	out	duties.		In	addition,	it	includes	policies	and	communications	directed	at	ensuring	personnel	understand	the	entity's	objectives,	know	how	their	individual	actions	interrelate	and	contribute	to	those	objectives,	and	recognize	how	and	for	what	they	will	be	held	accountable.	Organizational	charts	are	in	place	to	communicate	key	areas	of	authority	and	responsibility.	These	charts	are	accessible	to	all	employees	of	the	company	and	are	updated	as	required.		The	goal	of	the	organization	is	to	have	lean	and	agile	teams.	However,	every	team	member	is	part	of	a	formal	hierarchy	that	rolls	up	to	the	CEO.	While	employees	and	multiple	teams	may	collaborate	informally	to	get	things	done	faster,	in	case	of	conflicts	or	deciding	how	something	new	would	be	handled,	the	formal	hierarchy	is	used	as	the	basis	for	coming	to	conclusions.	It	is	also	ensured	that	collaborative	work	does	not	mean	sharing	of	confidential	data	or	credentials	that	must	not	be	shared	with	unauthorized	persons.	Specific	control	activities	that	the	service	organization	has	implemented	in	this	area	are	described	below:	● Organizational	charts	are	in	place	to	communicate	key	areas	of	authority	and	responsibility.	● Organizational	charts	are	communicated	to	employees	and	updated	as	needed.	Human	Resources	Policies	and	Practices	The	human	resource	department	under	the	direction	of	the	board	and	the	leadership	directs	the	policies	and	procedures	such	that	there	is:	● Delivery	excellence	● an	environment	where	merit	and	performance	are	valued.	● people	feel	part	of	something	bigger	than	them.	● a	high-performance	work	ethic	There	are	policies	that	dictate	induction	of	new	joiners,	exit	and	termination	policies	as	well	as	promotions	that	lead	to	achieving	the	goals	listed	above.

17		Risk	Assessment		Sharpsell’s	assessment	process	identifies	and	manages	risks	that	could	potentially	affect	Sharpsell’s	ability	to	provide	reliable	services	to	its	customers.	This	ongoing	process	requires	that	management	identify	significant	risks	inherent	in	products	or	services	as	they	oversee	their	areas	of	responsibility.	The	Sharpsell	identifies	the	underlying	sources	of	risk,	measures	the	impact	on	the	organization,	and	implements	appropriate	measures	to	monitor	and	manage	the	risks.	This	process	has	identified	risks	resulting	from	the	nature	of	the	services	provided	by	Sharpsell’	s	management	has	implemented	various	measures	designed	to	manage	these	risks.	Risks	identified	in	this	process	include	the	following:	● Operational	risk	-	changes	in	the	environment	and	critical	staff	● Strategic	risk	-	new	technologies,	changing	business	models,	and	shifts	within	the	industry.	● Compliance	-	legal	and	regulatory	changes	Sharpsell	has	established	an	internal	team	responsible	for	identifying	risks	to	the	entity	and	monitoring	the	operation	of	the	firm’s	internal	controls.	Sharpsell	attempts	to	actively	identify	and	mitigate	significant	risks	through	 the	 implementation	 of	 various	 initiatives	 and	 continuous	 communication	 with	 other	 leadership	committees	and	senior	management.	Information	and	Communications	Systems	It	 is	 important	 for	 the	customer	 and	 internal	 stakeholders	 to	 be	 aware	 of	 the	 changes	 to	 be	 made	 to	 the	production	systems	as	well	as	the	reasons	for	that.	The	same	applies	to	communications	after	the	changes	have	been	made	or	rolled	back.	Similarly,	a	new	initiative	taken	internally	to	add	product	features	or	to	improve	the	systems	in	any	other	way	needs	to	be	communicated	to	the	team	and	responsibilities	need	to	be	assigned.	That	requires	a	robust	and	efficient	mode	of	communication	that	is	also	secure.	Various	degrees	and	means	of	communication	are	required	for	interaction	with	prospects,	live	customers	and	employees.	In	addition,	it	is	required	to	keep	track	of	the	communications	as	well	as	what	actions	have	been	taken	to	achieve	the	goals.	Monitoring	Controls	Being	a	cloud-based	system,	the	monitoring	is	via	logs,	which	may	be	application	logs	as	well	as	access	logs.		A	dedicated	support	team	monitors	all	the	production	systems	24	x	7	and	keeps	an	eye	out	for	anomalies.	The	support	team	also	receives	issues	raised	by	the	customer	and	attempts	to	correlate	the	customer’s	findings	with	the	corresponding	logs,	thereby	pre-empting	a	customer	report	by	taking	corrective	action	even	before	it	is	reported	by	them.	Log	monitoring	is	also	used	to	pass	on	valuable	information	to	the	development	teams	to	solve	issues	that	cannot	be	simulated	in	a	development	environment.	On-Going	Monitoring

18		Sharpsell’s	management	conducts	quality	assurance	monitoring	on	a	regular	basis	and	additional	training	is	provided	based	upon	results	of	monitoring	procedures.	Monitoring	activities	are	used	to	initiate	corrective	action	through	department	meetings,	internal	conference	calls,	and	informal	notifications.	Management’s	 close	 involvement	in	 Sharpsell’s	 operations	 helps	 to	 identify	 significant	 variances	 from	expectations	regarding	internal	controls.	Upper	management	evaluates	the	facts	and	circumstances	related	to	any	suspected	control	breakdown.	A	decision	for	addressing	any	control’s	weakness	is	made	based	on	whether	the	 incident	 was	 isolated	 or	 requires	 a	 change	 in	 the	 company’s	 procedures	 or	 personnel.	 The	 goal	 of	 this	process	is	to	ensure	legal	compliance	and	to	maximize	the	performance	of	Sharpsell’s	personnel.	Reporting	Deficiencies	An	 internal	 tracking	 tool	 is	 utilized	 to	 document	 and	 track	 the	 results	 of	 on-going	 monitoring	 procedures.	Escalation	procedures	are	maintained	for	responding	and	notifying	management	of	any	identified	risks.	Risks	receiving	a	high	rating	are	responded	to	immediately.	Corrective	actions,	if	necessary,	are	documented	and	tracked	within	the	internal	tracking	tool.	Annual	risk	meetings	are	held	for	management	to	review	reported	deficiencies	and	corrective	actions. Incidents	Since	the	Last	Review	Since	the	organisation's	last	review,	no	significant	incidents	have	occurred	with	the	services	provided	to	user	entities.	Applicable	Trust	Service	Criteria	and	Related	Controls	The	 security,	 availability	 and	 confidentiality	 trust	 services	 categories	 and	 Sharpsell’s	 related	 controls	 are	included	 in	 section	 4	 of	 this	 report,	 “Independent	 Service	Auditor's	 Description	 of	 Tests	 of	 Controls	 and	Results”.	 Sharpsell	 has	 determined	 that	 Processing	 Integrity	 and	 Privacy	 trust	 services	 Categories	 are	 not	relevant	to	the	system.	Subservice	Organizations	This	report	does	not	include	the	data	center	hosting	services	provided	by	AWS	at	multiple	facilities.	Subservice	Description	of	Services	The	SAAS	services	provided	by	AWS	are	monitored	by	management;	however,	they	have	not	been	included	in	the	scope	of	this	review.	Complementary	Subservice	Organization	Controls	Sharpsell’s	services	are	designed	with	the	assumption	that	certain	controls	will	be	implemented	by	subservice	organizations.	Such	controls	are	called	complementary	subservice	organization	controls.	It	is	not	feasible	for	all	 of	 the	 trust	 services	 criteria	 related	 to	 the	 Sharpsell	 services	 to	 be	 solely	 achieved	 by	 Sharpsell	 control	procedures.	Accordingly,	subservice	organizations,	in	conjunction	with	the	services,	should	establish	their	own	internal	controls	or	procedures	to	complement	those	of	Sharpsell.

19		The	following	subservice	organization	controls	should	be	implemented	by	AWS	to	provide	additional	assurance	that	the	trust	services	criteria	described	within	this	report	are	met.		Subservice	Organization	–	AWS	Category	Criteria	Applicable	Controls	Common	Criteria/Security	CC6.4	Physical	access	to	data	centers	is	approved	by	an	authorized	individual.	Physical	access	is	revoked	within	24	hours	of	the	employee	or	vendor	record	being	deactivated.	Physical	access	to	data	centers	is	reviewed	on	a	quarterly	basis	by	appropriate	personnel.	Physical	access	points	to	server	locations	are	recorded	by	closed	circuit	television	camera	(CCTV).	Images	are	retained	for	60	days,	unless	limited	by	legal	or	contractual	obligations.	Physical	access	points	to	server	locations	are	managed	by	electronic	access	control	devices.	Availability	A1.2	Electronic	intrusion	detection	systems	are	installed	within	data	server	locations	to	monitor,	detect,	and	automatically	alert	appropriate	personnel	of	security	incidents.		Sharpsell	 management,	 along	 with	 the	 subservice	 organization,	 define	 the	 scope	 and	 responsibility	 of	 the	controls	necessary	to	meet	all	the	relevant	trust	services	criteria	through	written	contracts,	such	as	service	level	agreements.	In	addition,	Sharpsell	performs	monitoring	of	the	subservice	organization	controls,	including	the	following	procedures.	● Reviewing	attestation	reports	over	services	provided	by	vendors	and	subservice	organizations.		Complementary	Customer	Control	(CUEC)		Sharpsell’s	controls	related	to	Sharpsell	cover	a	subset	of	overall	internal	control	for	each	user	of	the	software	application.	The	control	objectives	related	to	Sharpsell	cannot	be	achieved	solely	by	the	controls	put	in	place	by	Sharpsell;	each	customer's	internal	controls	need	to	be	considered	along	with	Sharpsell’s	controls.	Each	customer	must	evaluate	its	own	internal	control	to	determine	whether	the	identified	complementary	customer	controls	have	been	implemented	and	are	operating	effectively.

Consultants performed a discovery  process to gather information about the target and searched  for 
information disclosure vulnerabilities. With this data in hand, we conducted the bulk of the  testing 
manually, which consisted of input validation tests, impersonation (authentication and authorization) tests, 
and session state management tests.  
The purpose of this penetration testing is to illuminate security risks by leveraging weaknesses within the 
environment that lead to the obtainment of unauthorized access and/or the retrieval of sensitive 
information. The shortcomings identified during the  assessment were used to formulate recommendations 
and mitigation strategies for improving the overall security posture.

Confidential | CyberComply  8 
   
 
Results  Overview  
Security  experts  performed  manual  security  testing  according  to OWASP  APIs Testing  
Methodology,  which  demonstrate s the following  results  of Open findings . 
 
Critical  High  Medium  Low  Informational  
0 0 0 0 0 
 
Severity  scoring:  
 
● Critical  - Immediate threat to key business processes.  
● High  – Direct threat to key business processes.  
● Medium  – Indirect threat to key business processes or partial threat to business  processes.  
● Low  – No direct  threat  exists.  Vulnerability  may be exploited  using  other  vulnerabilities.  
● Informational – This finding does not indicate vulnerability but states a comment that  notifies  
about  design  flaws  and improper  implementation  that might  cause  a problem  in the long run.

Confidential | CyberComply  9 
   
Summary  of business  risks 
Medium and low severity issues can lead to:  
● Attacks on communication channels and as a result on sensitive data leakage and  possible 
modification, in other words , it affects the integrity and confidentiality of data  transferred.  
● Information leakage about system components may be used by attackers for  further  malicious  
actions.  
● Attacks on old and not patched system components with bunch of publicly known  vulnerabilities.  
● Enumerating  existing  user's  emails/usernames  and brute  forcing  their passwords.  Easy  access  to their 
session  after exploitation  of high-level  risks.  
● A combination  of a few  issues can be used for the successful realization  of attacks.  
Informational  severity  issues  do not carry  direct  threat s, but they can be  used to gather useful  information  
for an attacker.  
 
High -Level Recommendations  
Taking into consideration all issues that have been discovered, we highly recommend to:  
● Review Architecture of the application  
● Implement Patch Management procedures for the whole IT infrastructure and endpoints of 
employees and developers.  
● Continuously Patch production and development environments and systems regularly  with the 
latest releases and security updates  
● Conduct annual Penetration test s and quarterly Vulnerability Scanning against internal and external 
environment s. 
● Develop and Conduct Security Awareness training for employees and developers.  
● Develop Incident Response Plan in case of Data breach or security incidents.  
● Analyze  risks for key assets and resources.  
● Updat e the codebase to conduct verification and sanitization of user input on both the client  and 
server side. 
● Use only encrypted channels for communications.  
● Do not send any unnecessary data in requests and cookies.  
● Improve server and application configuration to meet security best practices.

Graphical Summary:

Confidential | CyberComply  12 
   
Findings  Details  
 
#1. Insecure Token Storage and Transmission  
SEVERITY:  MEDIUM  
STATUS:  CLOSED  
 
LOCATION:  All APIs (Sharpsell)  
 
DESCRIPTION:  Bearer tokens are used to authenticate API requests. In this case, the token is encoded using 
Base64, which is not a secure method of encryption. Base64 encoding simply converts binary data into a text 
string, making it easily decodable with tools like Burp Suite. As a result, sensitive information such as user 
details and encryption parameters are exposed, which can lead to various security risks.  
 
IMPACT:  An attacker intercepts an API request using a tool like Burp Suite and notices the bearer token is 
Base64 encoded. The attacker decodes the token and extracts sensitive information such as the user's phone 
number and other details. Using this information, the attacker attempts to impersonate the user or perform 
other malicious activities on the application. By understanding the encryption details exposed in the token, the 
attacker may also try to break the encryption or find other vulnerabilities in  the system.  
 
In summary, the use of Base64 encoding for bearer tokens is a serious vulnerability that can lead to sensitive 
data exposure and other security risks. It is essential to use proper encryption methods and follow best practices 
for token management and trans mission.  
 
PROOF  OF VULNERABILITY:  
Send the request to Burp suite and see the Bearer Token  
 
JWT (JSON Web Tokens) is implemented, Hence, it’s  not a finding ( Closed ). 
 
RECOMMENDATIONS : 
 
Ensure that bearer tokens are encrypted using a strong encryption algorithm instead of just being Base64 
encoded. Use techniques such as JWT (JSON Web Tokens) with a strong secret and appropriate encryption.

Confidential | CyberComply  13 
   
#2. Mass User Registration Vulnerability  
SEVERITY:  MEDIUM  
STATUS:  CLOSED  
 
LOCATION:   
 
• https://sharpselltech.enparadigmtech.com/core/v1/admin/user  
• https://sharpselltech.enparadigmtech.com/pyapi/banners/  
• https:// sharpselltech.enparadigmtech.com /pyapi/highlights/  
                                                  
DESCRIPTION:  The vulnerability arises when an API endpoint allows unrestricted user creation without 
any mechanisms to limit or verify the number of accounts that can be created in a given timeframe. This allows 
an attacker to exploit the functionality and create a large number of user accounts automatically.  When this 
control is missing or improperly configured, it allows an attacker to send an excessive number of requests in 
a short period, potentially overwhelming the server or exploiting the functionality of the application.  
 
In this case, using Burp Suite Intruder, we were able to create more than 300 user accounts rapidly, indicating 
that the API endpoint for user creation does not have proper rate limiting in place.  
 
IMPACT:   
 
• Denial of Service (DoS): A large number of requests can overwhelm the server, leading to degraded 
performance or complete unavailability of the service.  
• Resource Exhaustion: Creating numerous user accounts can consume significant server resources, 
such as memory and storage, affecting the overall system performance.  
 
PROOF  OF VULNERABILITY:  
Frist login and go to the user creation field in postman and send the request to Burp Suite.  
 
Now capture the request and send to intruder then add the specific position .

Confidential | CyberComply  14 
   
Below you can see that in the request and response we are getting the 200 ok and also in the response user 
creation success message is clearly visible  
 
 
Implemented rate limiting, ensuring a maximum of 10 requests per second with a peak capacity of 20 requests 
per second during high traffic periods  , Hence, it’s not a finding ( Closed ). 
 
RECOMMENDATIONS : 
 
Implement Rate Limiting: Ensure that the API endpoint enforces rate limiting to restrict the number of requests 
a user can make in a given time frame.

Confidential | CyberComply  15

server side.

Findings  Details  
 
#1. Unrestricted File Upload  
SEVERITY:  MEDIUM  
STATUS:  CLOSED  
 
LOCATION:  All Upload fields  
 
• https://sharpselltech.enparadigmtech.com /admin/users , 
• https:// sharpselltech.enparadigmtech.com /admin/branding -config  
 
DESCRIPTION:  An Unrestricted File Upload vulnerability occurs when a web application allows the 
uploading of files without properly validating the file type, content, and size. This can lead to the upload of 
malicious files, such as executable scripts, which can be executed on the server.  
 
IMPACT:   
 
• Remote Code Execution: An attacker can upload and execute malicious scripts or executables, gaining 
control over the server.  
• Server Compromise: An attacker can upload web shells, allowing them to perform arbitrary operations 
on the server, including data theft, defacement, and further penetration into the network.  
 
PROOF  OF VULNERABILITY:  
Created the dummy Test .Bat file for testing  
 
Now login to the web application and go to the page where user creation page is located, upload the .bat file

Confidential | CyberComply  10 
 
 
As we can see above the .Bat file  unable upload  and its giving the error , Hence, it’s  not a finding (Closed) . 
 
RECOMMENDATIONS : 
• File Type Validation: Only allow specific, trusted file types to be uploaded. This can be achieved by 
checking the file extension and validating the MIME type on both the client -side and server -side. 
• Rename Files: Rename uploaded files to a secure format to prevent malicious file names from being 
executed. For example, replace the file extension with a harmless one or use a unique identifier for the 
file name.  
• Use a Whitelist: Implement a whitelist of allowed file types and reject any files not on the list.

Confidential | CyberComply  11 
 
#2. Banner Flooding  vulnerability  
SEVERITY:  MEDIUM  
STATUS:  CLOSED  
 
LOCATION:  https:// sharpselltech.enparadigmtech.com /admin/plugins/banners  
                                                  
DESCRIPTION:  Banner flooding occurs when an application allows users to create a large number of banners 
or similar objects rapidly, leading to resource exhaustion and potential denial -of-service (DoS) conditions. 
This vulnerability can be exploited by automated tools like Burp Intruder to flood the system with excessive 
banner creations.  
 
IMPACT:  Resource Exhaustion: The rapid creation of numerous banners consumes system resources such as 
memory, CPU, and storage, potentially leading to performance degradation or system instability.  
Denial of Service (DoS): If the application does not have adequate controls to limit banner creation, an attacker 
could flood the system with banners, causing legitimate users to experience service disruptions or denial of 
access.  
 
PROOF  OF VULNERABILITY:  
Frist login and go to the banner creation field   
 
Now capture the request and send to intruder then add the specific position where we have send the data,  
 
Below you can see that in the request and response we are getting the 200 ok and also in the response user 
creation success message is clearly visible

Confidential | CyberComply  12 
 
 
 
Implemented rate limiting, ensuring a maximum of 10 requests per second with a peak capacity of 20 requests  
per second during high traffic periods, Hence, it’s not a finding (Closed).  
 
RECOMMENDATIONS : 
 
Rate Limiting: Implement rate -limiting mechanisms to control the number of banners that can be created 
within a specific time frame. This helps prevent abuse and reduces the impact of banner flooding attacks.  
Input Validation: Validate user input for banner creation to ensure it complies with expected formats and 
limits. Reject excessive or malformed requests to create banners.

Confidential | CyberComply  13 
   
#3. Improper URL Handling / Path Traversal  
SEVERITY:  LOW  
STATUS : CLOSED  
 
LOCATION : https:// sharpselltech.enparadigmtech.com /admin/login  
 
DESCRIPTION:  When an application allows users to bypass normal authentication mechanisms by 
manipulating the URL (such as adding /../../../ at the end), it indicates a failure to properly validate and sanitize 
input paths. This can lead to unintended access to parts of  the application that should be restricted.  
 
IMPACT:   
• Unauthorized Access: Attackers can access restricted parts of the application, such as pages requiring 
different authentication methods or more privileged access.  
• Security Bypass: This vulnerability can be exploited to bypass Single Sign -On (SSO) or OTP -based 
authentication mechanisms, potentially leading to unauthorized access to sensitive information or 
functions.  
• Information Disclosure: Exposing different login mechanisms (like a username and password login 
screen) can provide attackers with additional attack vectors, such as brute -force attacks.  
 
PROOF  OF VULNERABILITY:  
Step 1: hit the url in the browser  
 
Now add at the last of the url ( ‘ )

Confidential | CyberComply  14 
   
Now it will redirect to to page not found  
Now add ( /../../ )  
 
Now we hit and check the response  
  
As per the justification “intentionally  allow URL  to ensure accessibility and visibility of content, aligning with 
our strategic goal of maximizing user engagement and reach ”, Hence , it’s not a finding ( Closed ). 
 
 
RECOMMENDATIONS : 
• Input Validation: Ensure all user inputs, including URL paths, are validated and sanitized. This helps 
prevent path traversal attacks and unauthorized URL access.  
• Access Control: Implement strict access control checks on the server -side to verify that users are 
authenticated and authorized to access specific resources or pages. Do not rely solely on URL patterns 
for access control.

Operational
Procedures
●
Employees
may
request
changes
to
the
firewall’ s
configuration
in
order 
to
allow
previously
disallowed
traffic.
A
change
request
with
full 
justification
must
be
submitted
to
the
IT
department
for
approval.
All 
requests
will
be
assessed
to
determine
if
they
fall
within
the
parameters 
of
acceptable
risk.
Approval
is
not
guaranteed
as
associated
risks
may 
be
deemed
too
high.
If
this
is
the
case,
an
explanation
will
be
provided
to 
the
original
requestor
and
alternative
solutions
will
be
explored.
●
Employees
may
request
access
from
the
Internet
for
services
located
on 
the
internal
Company’ s
network.
Typically ,
this
remote
access
is
handled 
via
a
secure,
encrypted
virtual
private
network
(VPN)
connection.
●
An
inactivity
timeout
will
be
set
for
VPN
sessions
[30
Min].
At
the
end
of 
these
timeout
periods,
users
must
re-authenticate
to
continue
or
re- 
establish
their
VPN
connection.
A
VPN
connectivity
request
has
to
raise 
with
full
justification,
to
the
IT
department
for
approval.
Approval
is 
subject
to
business
requirements.
●
From
time
to
time,
outside
vendors,
contractors,
or
other
entities
may 
require
secure,
short-term,
remote
access
to
Company's
internal 
network.
If
such
a
need
arises,
a
third-party
access
request
has
to
be 
raised
with
full
justification
and
must
be
submitted
to
the
IT
department 
for
approval.
Approval
is
subject
to
business
requirements.
●
Turnaround
time
for
the
above-stated
firewall
reconfiguration
and 
network
access
requests
is
approximately
2
days
from
the
receipt
of
the 
request.
●
Firewall
logs
will
be
backed
up
every
day
and
archived
for
3
months. 
Firewall
logs
will
be
reviewed
daily .

Company
Profile
1.1
Overview
We
are
a
sales
playbook
automation
company
focused
on
driving
productivity
across
organizations.
Our 
products
and
solutions
help
solve
for
two
major
issues
faced
by
organizations,
driving
productivity
of
teams 
across
the
organization.
Sharpsell
comes
with
playbooks
for
sales
people
that
adapt
and
serve
them
every
step
of
the
sales
process 
by:
providing
learning,
content,
tools,
frameworks
and
answers
that
are
required
to
build
trust
and
close 
deals.
It
is
an
automation
platform
that
helps
sales
learning
and
transformation
teams
scale
and
replicate
best 
practices
and
winning
behaviour
across
the
sales
force
for
successful
outcomes.
It
comes
with
purpose
built 
content
presets,
dynamic
presentation
engines
and
out-of-box
integrations
to
make
implementation
a
breeze.
We
include
actionable
analytics
and
a
host
of
support
tools
to
help
you
better
orient
interventions
and
track 
impact.
Vision
Statement 
Enable
50
million+
employees
and
frontline
workforce
to
become
sales
champions.
Mission
Statement 
●
Transform
every
seller
into
a
sales
champion 
●
Sales
people
strive
hard
to
understand
prospective
customers’
needs,
suggest
products
and
services 
that
make
their
lives
better. 
●
We
strive
hard
to
make
sales
people's
lives
better;
stress
free,
effective

solutions
may
limit
the
ability
to
achieve
high-level
project
objectives,
by
unnecessarily 
constraining
a
desirable
solution. 
●
Control 
Control-based
responses
occur
at
all
points
throughout
the
development
lifecycle
and
are
typically 
the
most
common
response.
This
helps
in
minimizing
the
impact
of
the
risk.
They
identify
an
action 
or
product
that
becomes
part
of
the
cell
or
area
working
plans,
and
which
are
monitored
and
reported 
as
part
of
the
regular
performance
analysis
and
progress
reporting
of
the
project. 
●
Transfer 
Transfer-based
responses
target
the
party
who
is
best
placed
to
analyze
and
implement
the 
response
to
the
risk,
based
on
their
expertise,
experience,
and
suitability.
Typical
transfer
responses 
include
the
sub-contracting
to
specialist
suppliers
who
are
able
to
reduce
the
overall
risk
exposure. 
Another
example
could
be
having
an
insurance
cover
where
the
impact
is
transferred
from
the 
insured
party
to
the
insurance
provider. 
●
Investigation 
Investigation-based
responses
do
not
define
any
mitigation
for
reducing
an
individual
risk.
They
are 
responses
to
risks
where
no
clear
solution
is
identified,
and
further
research
is
required.

Typical
transfer
responses 
include
the
sub-contracting
to
specialist
suppliers
who
are
able
to
reduce
the
overall
risk
exposure. 
Another

could
be
having
an
insurance
cover
where
the
impact
is
transferred
from
the 
insured
party
to
the
insurance
provider. 
●
Investigation 
Investigation-based
responses
do
not
define
any
mitigation
for
reducing
an
individual
risk.
They
are 
responses
to
risks
where
no
clear
solution
is
identified,
and
further
research
is
required.
However, 
investigative
responses
should
not
be
ignored,
as
they
immediately
and
directly
lead
to
a
greater 
aggregated
project
risk.
This
is
because
the
probability
for
each
risk
includes
the
effect
of
the
applied 
response,
for
which
there
is
none,
and
the
level
of
control
indicates
the
level
of
influence
to
apply
that 
response,
which
is
low.

Mobile
Device
Policy
The
following
control
procedures
are
applicable
to
mobile
computing
resources.
a)
Associates
who
use
laptops
and
connected
to
office
network
will
maintain
the
business
information
on
their
respective
company
common
storage
areas.
b)
Associates
will
ensure
that
’Confidential’
information
are
stored
on

based
on
business
need
only.
Internal
auditors
will

at

and
any
deviation
found

will
be
treated
as
violation
of
security
policy.
c)

will
ensure
to
back
up
the
business
information
created
or
modified
while
on
tour.
d)
Associates
will
ensure
that
Laptops
are
physically
secured
at
all
times.
When

by
the
physical
presence

associates,

should

in

secure
area

a

e)

will

laptops
are
not
checked

luggage,

It

hand

or
a
laptop
carrying
case.
f)
Associates
will
ensure
that
laptops
are
never
left
unattended
in
cars
or
at
airports.
g)
Associates
who
travel
with
a
laptop
or
other
Company
equipment
or
information,
including
briefcases
will
be
cautious
and
keep
the
items
with
them
at
all
times.
h)
Associates
should
not
leave
laptops
in
hotel
rooms.
The
hotel
should
be
asked
whether
they
could
secure
the
laptop,
else
the
laptop
should
be
locked
inside
luggage
and

out
of
sight.
If
the
laptop
has
a
removable
hard
drive,
it
should

another
location.
i)

and

16.1
Information
Security
Continuity
16.1.1
Planning
Information
Security
Continuity
Function
Heads/
PMs
will
follow
a
risk
assessment
or
strategy
plan
to
assist
in
the
development
and 
approach
of
the
business
continuity
plan.
The
risk
assessment
will
identify
all
key
systems,
critical
business 
functions,
and
the
threats
to
those
assets.
The
threats
include,
but
are
not
limited
to:
●
Natural
disasters 
●
Fire 
●
Loss
of
critical
infrastructure
services
such
as
electricity,
communications
or
water 
●
Deliberate
or
accidental
damage
to
equipment
or
data 
●
Strikes
or
labor
disruptions 
●
System
failures 
●
Security
breaches 
●
Deliberate
or
accidental
disclosure
of
confidential
or
proprietary
information.
Function
Heads/
PMs
will
determine
the
likely
impact
of
these
threats
for
each
asset,
including
a
damage 
analysis
and
priorities
for
recovery.
The
plan
will
clearly
define
recovery
time
objectives
and
minimum 
acceptable
recovery
resources.

16.2.1
Availability
of
information
processing
facilities:
Business
Continuity
Management
(as
defined
by
the
Business
Continuity
Institute
2001)
is:
‘A
holistic 
management
process
that
identifies
potential
impacts
that
threaten
an
organization
and
provides
a 
framework
for
building
resilience
with
the
capability
for
an
effective
response
that
safeguards
the
interests 
of
its
key
stakeholders,
reputation,
brand
and
value-creating
activities’.
Business
Continuity
Management
is
concerned
with
managing
risk
to
ensure
that,
at
all
times,
the 
organization
can
continue
operating
to,
at
least,
a
predetermined
minimum
level,
in
the
event
of
a
major 
disruption.
These
risks
can
be
from
the
external
environment
e.g.
power
failures,
severe
weather,
or
from 
within
the
organization
e.g.
system
failures,
loss
of
key
staff.
The
primary
objective
of
Business
Continuity
planning
is
to
protect
the
organization
in
the
event
that
all
or 
part
of
its
operations
and/or
computer
services
is
rendered
unusable.
The
planning
process
should
minimize 
the
disruption
of
operations
and
ensure
some
level
of
organizational
stability
and
an
orderly
recovery
after
a 
disaster.
Other
objective
of
disaster
recovery
planning
includes:
●
Providing
a
sense
of
security
●
Minimizing
risk
of
delays
●
Guaranteeing
the
reliability
of
standby
systems
●
Providing
a
standard
for
testing
the
plan.
●
Minimizing
decision-making
during
a
disaster

Important

and

shall

of

rights
when
personal
data
are

storage
and
transmission
must
comply
with
the
data
protection
legislation);

review
of

Security
The

checking

and
quality
of
the
manual
itself
against
best
practice
reference
standards
including
ISO
27001.
The

security
controls
in

throughout
Company
shall

annually
against

Security
Policy
Manual

security

or

and
retained.

This report presents the results of the “Grey Box” penetration testing for Sharpsell  iOS 
Application.  The recommendations  provided  in this report  are structured  to facilitate  remediation 
of the  identified security risks. This document serves as a formal letter of attestation for the recent  
Sharpsell  Grey  Box iOS App  Penetration  Testing.

Assumptions  & Constraints  
As the environment changes, and new vulnerabilities and risks are discovered and made  public, 
an organization’s overall security posture will change. Such changes may affect the  validity of 
this letter. Therefore, the conclusion reached from our analysis only represents a  “snapshot”  in 
time.

Consultants performed a discovery  process to gather information about the target and searched  for 
information disclosure vulnerabilities. With this data in hand, we conducted the bulk of the  testing 
manually, which consisted of input validation tests, impersonation (authentication and  
authorization) tests, and session state management tests. The purpose of this penetration  testing  is 
to illuminate  security  risks by leveraging  weaknesses  within  the environment  that lead to the 
obtainment of unauthorized access and/or the retrieval of sensitive information. The  shortcomings  
identified  during  the assessment  were  used to formulate  recommendations  and mitigation  strategies  
for improving  the overall  security  posture.

Confidential | CyberComply  4 
 
Results  Overview  
The test uncovered a few vulnerabilities that may cause sensitive data leakage, broken  
confidentiality  and integrity  and availability  of the resource.  
 
 
 
Security  experts  performed  manual  security  testing  according  to OWASP  Mobile  Application  
Testing  Methodology,  which  demonstrates  the following  results  of Open findings . 
 
Severity  scoring:  
 
● Critical  - Immediate  threat  to key business  processes.  
● High  – Direct  threat  to key business  processes.  
● Medium  – Indirect threat to key business processes or partial threat to business  processes.  
● Low  – No direct  threat  exists.  Vulnerability  may be exploited  using  other  vulnerabilities.  
● Informational  – This finding does not indicate vulnerability but  states a comment that  notifies  
about  design  flaws  and improper  implementation  that might  cause  a problem  in the long run.

Summary  of business  risks 
Medium  and low severity  issues  can lead to: 
● Attacks on communication channels and as a result on sensitive data leakage and  possible 
modification, in other words it affects the integrity and confidentiality of data  transferred.  
● Information leakage about system components which may be used by attackers for  further  
malicious  actions.  
● Attacks on old and not patched system components with bunch of publicly known  
vulnerabilities.  
● Enumerating  existing  user's  emails/usernames  and brute  forcing  their passwords.  Easy  
access  to their session  after exploitation  of high-level  risks.  
● A combination  of a few  issues  can be used for successful  realization  of attacks.  
Informational  severity  issues  do not carry  direct  threat,  but they can be  used to gather useful  
information  for an attacker.  
 
High -Level  Recommendations  
Taking  into consideration  all issues  that have been discovered,  we highly  recommend  to: 
● Conduct current vs. future IT/Security program review.  
● Conduct Static code analysis for codebase.  
● Establish Secure SDLC best practices, assign Security Engineer to a project to monthly review 
code, conduct SAST & DAST security testing.  
● Review Architecture of application  
● Continuously Patch production and development environments and systems on regular bases with 
latest releases and security updates  
● Conduct annual Penetration test and quarterly Vulnerability Scanning against internal and external 
environment.  
● Develop and Conduct Security Awareness training for employees and developers.  
● Develop Incident Response Plan in case of Data breach or security incidents.  
● Analyze  risks for key assets and resources.  
● Update codebase to conduct verification and sanitization of user input on both client and server 
side. 
● Use only encrypted channels for communications.  
● Do not send any unnecessary data in requests and cookies.  
● Improve server and application configuration to meet security best practices.

Confidential | CyberComply  8 
 
Findings  Details  
 
#1. URL Scheme Hijacking  
SEVERITY:  HIGH  
 
STATUS:  CLOSED  
 
LOCATION:  IPA file  
 
DESCRIPTION:  If another application registers the same URL scheme (sharpsell), it could potentially 
intercept or spoof URL requests intended for your app.  
 
IMPACT : If the application does not validate and sanitize the data received through the custom URL scheme, 
it may be vulnerable to attacks such as command injection, data manipulation, or other injection attacks.  
 
PROOF  OF VULNERABILITY:  
 
 
 
As confirmed, Sharpsell utilizes a unique "sharpsell" schema for internal links and enforces HTTPS for 
external links, ensuring robust deep linking and enhancing overall application security , hence it  is not a 
finding  (Closed) . 
 
RECOMMENDATIONS : 
• Unique URL Scheme:  Use a unique and complex URL scheme to avoid conflicts with other 
applications.  
Example:  
 
• Least Privilege:  Limit the functionality accessible via the custom URL scheme to the minimum 
necessary for the app's operation.

highly accessible to both management and operational staff. Each finding will have a risk scoring

finding. Each finding will also be presented with clear guidance on how to remediate the issue.
